chunk: There are 14 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Boot or Logon Autostart Execution. Their names are as follows: * Shortcut Modification * Kernel Modules and Extensions * Re-opened Applications * Winlogon Helper DLL * Security Support Provider * Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder * LSASS Driver * Print Processors * Active Setup * Login Items * XDG Autostart Entries * Time Providers * Authentication Package * Port Monitors The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution Attack technique description: Adversaries may configure system settings to automatically execute a program during system boot or logon to maintain persistence or gain higher-level privileges on compromised systems. Operating systems may have mechanisms for automatically running a program on system boot or account logon.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key)(Citation: MSDN Authentication Packages)(Citation: Microsoft TimeProvider)(Citation: Cylance Reg Persistence Sept 2013)(Citation: Linux Kernel Programming) These mechanisms may include automatically executing programs that are placed in specially designated directories or are referenced by repositories that store configuration information, such as the Windows Registry. An adversary may achieve the same goal by modifying or extending features of the kernel. Since some boot or logon autostart programs run with higher privileges, an adversary may leverage these to elevate privileges. Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows, Network Attack technique name: Shortcut Modification Attack technique description: Adversaries may create or modify shortcuts that can execute a program during system boot or user login. Shortcuts or symbolic links are used to reference other files or programs that will be opened or executed when the shortcut is clicked or executed by a system startup process. Adversaries may abuse shortcuts in the startup folder to execute their tools and achieve persistence.(Citation: Shortcut for Persistence ) Although often used as payloads in an infection chain (e.g. [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001)), adversaries may also create a new shortcut as a means of indirection, while also abusing [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to make the malicious shortcut appear as a legitimate program. Adversaries can also edit the target path or entirely replace an existing shortcut so their malware will be executed instead of the intended legitimate program. Shortcuts can also be abused to establish persistence by implementing other methods. For example, LNK browser extensions may be modified (e.g. [Browser Extensions](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1176)) to persistently launch malware. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Kernel Modules and Extensions Attack technique description: Adversaries may modify the kernel to automatically execute programs on system boot. Loadable Kernel Modules (LKMs) are pieces of code that can be loaded and unloaded into the kernel upon demand. They extend the functionality of the kernel without the need to reboot the system. For example, one type of module is the device driver, which allows the kernel to access hardware connected to the system.(Citation: Linux Kernel Programming)  When used maliciously, LKMs can be a type of kernel-mode [Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1014) that run with the highest operating system privilege (Ring 0).(Citation: Linux Kernel Module Programming Guide) Common features of LKM based rootkits include: hiding itself, selective hiding of files, processes and network activity, as well as log tampering, providing authenticated backdoors, and enabling root access to non-privileged users.(Citation: iDefense Rootkit Overview) Kernel extensions, also called kext, are used in macOS to load functionality onto a system similar to LKMs for Linux. Since the kernel is responsible for enforcing security and the kernel extensions run as apart of the kernel, kexts are not governed by macOS security policies. Kexts are loaded and unloaded through kextload and kextunload commands. Kexts need to be signed with a developer ID that is granted privileges by Apple allowing it to sign Kernel extensions. Developers without these privileges may still sign kexts but they will not load unless SIP is disabled. If SIP is enabled, the kext signature is verified before being added to the AuxKC.(Citation: System and kernel extensions in macOS) Since macOS Catalina 10.15, kernel extensions have been deprecated in favor of System Extensions. However, kexts are still allowed as "Legacy System Extensions" since there is no System Extension for Kernel Programming Interfaces.(Citation: Apple Kernel Extension Deprecation) Adversaries can use LKMs and kexts to conduct [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003) and/or [Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0004) on a system. Examples have been found in the wild, and there are some relevant open source projects as well.(Citation: Volatility Phalanx2)(Citation: CrowdStrike Linux Rootkit)(Citation: GitHub Reptile)(Citation: GitHub Diamorphine)(Citation: RSAC 2015 San Francisco Patrick Wardle)(Citation: Synack Secure Kernel Extension Broken)(Citation: Securelist Ventir)(Citation: Trend Micro Skidmap) Platforms: macOS, Linux Attack technique name: Re-opened Applications Attack technique description: Adversaries may modify plist files to automatically run an application

entities.name: BOOT OR LOGON AUTOSTART EXECUTION
entities.description: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution is an attack technique where adversaries configure system settings to automatically execute a program during system boot or logon to maintain persistence or gain higher-level privileges on compromised systems.

entities.name: SHORTCUT MODIFICATION
entities.description: Shortcut Modification is an attack technique where adversaries create or modify shortcuts that can execute a program during system boot or user login, often used to achieve persistence.

entities.name: KERNEL MODULES AND EXTENSIONS
entities.description: Kernel Modules and Extensions is an attack technique where adversaries modify the kernel to automatically execute programs on system boot, using Loadable Kernel Modules (LKMs) or kernel extensions (kexts) in macOS.

entities.name: RE-OPENED APPLICATIONS
entities.description: Re-opened Applications is an attack technique where adversaries modify plist files to automatically run an application during system boot or user login.

entities.name: PRINT PROCESSORS
entities.description: Print Processors are components that can be exploited by adversaries to execute malicious code during print jobs, potentially maintaining persistence.

entities.name: ACTIVE SETUP
entities.description: Active Setup is a mechanism that can be used by adversaries to execute programs during user logon, allowing for persistence.

entities.name: LOGIN ITEMS
entities.description: Login Items are applications that can be set to run automatically when a user logs in, which adversaries may manipulate for persistence.

entities.name: XDG AUTOSTART ENTRIES
entities.description: XDG Autostart Entries are used in Linux environments to automatically start applications during user login, which can be exploited by adversaries.

entities.name: TIME PROVIDERS
entities.description: Time Providers are components that can be manipulated to execute programs at specific times, potentially aiding in persistence.

entities.name: AUTHENTICATION PACKAGE
entities.description: Authentication Package is a component that can be exploited by adversaries to gain higher-level privileges during the authentication process.

entities.name: PORT MONITORS
entities.description: Port Monitors are components that can be used by adversaries to execute malicious code during print jobs, contributing to persistence.

key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Boot or Logon Autostart Execution is an attack technique where adversaries configure system settings to automatically execute a program during system boot or logon to maintain persistence or gain higher-level privileges on compromised systems.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="SHORTCUT MODIFICATION">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Shortcut Modification is an attack technique where adversaries create or modify shortcuts that can execute a program during system boot or user login, often used to achieve persistence.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="KERNEL MODULES AND EXTENSIONS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Kernel Modules and Extensions is an attack technique where adversaries modify the kernel to automatically execute programs on system boot, using Loadable Kernel Modules (LKMs) or kernel extensions (kexts) in macOS.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="RE-OPENED APPLICATIONS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Re-opened Applications is an attack technique where adversaries modify plist files to automatically run an application during system boot or user login.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="PRINT PROCESSORS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Print Processors are components that can be exploited by adversaries to execute malicious code during print jobs, potentially maintaining persistence.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="ACTIVE SETUP">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Active Setup is a mechanism that can be used by adversaries to execute programs during user logon, allowing for persistence.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="LOGIN ITEMS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Login Items are applications that can be set to run automatically when a user logs in, which adversaries may manipulate for persistence.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="XDG AUTOSTART ENTRIES">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">XDG Autostart Entries are used in Linux environments to automatically start applications during user login, which can be exploited by adversaries.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="TIME PROVIDERS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Time Providers are components that can be manipulated to execute programs at specific times, potentially aiding in persistence.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="AUTHENTICATION PACKAGE">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Authentication Package is a component that can be exploited by adversaries to gain higher-level privileges during the authentication process.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="PORT MONITORS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Port Monitors chunk: 2)(Citation: CrowdStrike Linux Rootkit)(Citation: GitHub Reptile)(Citation: GitHub Diamorphine)(Citation: RSAC 2015 San Francisco Patrick Wardle)(Citation: Synack Secure Kernel Extension Broken)(Citation: Securelist Ventir)(Citation: Trend Micro Skidmap) Platforms: macOS, Linux Attack technique name: Re-opened Applications Attack technique description: Adversaries may modify plist files to automatically run an application when a user logs in. When a user logs out or restarts via the macOS Graphical User Interface (GUI), a prompt is provided to the user with a checkbox to "Reopen windows when logging back in".(Citation: Re-Open windows on Mac) When selected, all applications currently open are added to a property list file named com.apple.loginwindow.[UUID].plist within the ~/Library/Preferences/ByHost directory.(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence)(Citation: Wardle Persistence Chapter) Applications listed in this file are automatically reopened upon the user’s next logon. Adversaries can establish [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003) by adding a malicious application path to the com.apple.loginwindow.[UUID].plist file to execute payloads when a user logs in. Platforms: macOS Attack technique name: Winlogon Helper DLL Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse features of Winlogon to execute DLLs and/or executables when a user logs in. Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete. Registry entries in HKLM\Software[\\Wow6432Node\\]\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ are used to manage additional helper programs and functionalities that support Winlogon.(Citation: Cylance Reg Persistence Sept 2013) Malicious modifications to these Registry keys may cause Winlogon to load and execute malicious DLLs and/or executables. Specifically, the following subkeys have been known to be possibly vulnerable to abuse: (Citation: Cylance Reg Persistence Sept 2013) * Winlogon\Notify - points to notification package DLLs that handle Winlogon events * Winlogon\Userinit - points to userinit.exe, the user initialization program executed when a user logs on * Winlogon\Shell - points to explorer.exe, the system shell executed when a user logs on Adversaries may take advantage of these features to repeatedly execute malicious code and establish persistence. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Security Support Provider Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse security support providers (SSPs) to execute DLLs when the system boots. Windows SSP DLLs are loaded into the Local Security Authority (LSA) process at system start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Security Packages and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\OSConfig\Security Packages. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called.(Citation: Graeber 2014) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder Attack technique description: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key. Adding an entry to the "run keys" in the Registry or startup folder will cause the program referenced to be executed when a user logs in.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key) These programs will be executed under the context of the user and will have the account's associated permissions level. The following run keys are created by default on Windows systems: * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce Run keys may exist under multiple hives.(Citation: Microsoft Wow6432Node 2018)(Citation: Malwarebytes Wow6432Node 2016) The HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx is also available but is not created by default on Windows Vista and newer. Registry run key entries can reference programs directly or list them as a dependency.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key) For example, it is possible to load a DLL at logon using a "Depend" key with RunOnceEx: reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\0001\Depend /v 1 /d "C:\temp\evil[.]dll" (Citation: Oddvar Moe RunOnceEx Mar 2018) Placing a program within a startup folder will also cause that program to execute when a user logs in. There is a startup folder location for individual user accounts as well as a system-wide startup folder

entities.name: CROWDSTRIKE
entities.description: CrowdStrike is a cybersecurity technology company known for its endpoint protection and threat intelligence services.

entities.name: GITHUB
entities.description: GitHub is a platform for version control and collaboration, allowing developers to work together on projects from anywhere.

entities.name: RSAC 2015
entities.description: RSAC 2015 refers to the 2015 edition of the RSA Conference, a prominent event in the cybersecurity industry where experts gather to discuss security trends and technologies.

entities.description: Securelist is a cybersecurity research and analysis platform that provides insights into malware and cyber threats.

entities.name: TREND MICRO
entities.description: Trend Micro is a global cybersecurity company that provides security software and solutions for businesses and consumers.

entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system model that is widely used in servers, desktops, and embedded systems.

entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple Inc. for its line of Mac computers, known for its user-friendly interface and robust security features.

entities.name: WINDOWS

entities.name: DIAMORPHINE
entities.description: Diamorphine is a type of malware that can be used to exploit vulnerabilities in systems, particularly in the context of cybersecurity threats.

chunk: : reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\0001\Depend /v 1 /d "C:\temp\evil[.]dll" (Citation: Oddvar Moe RunOnceEx Mar 2018) Placing a program within a startup folder will also cause that program to execute when a user logs in. There is a startup folder location for individual user accounts as well as a system-wide startup folder that will be checked regardless of which user account logs in. The startup folder path for the current user is C:\Users\\[Username]\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup. The startup folder path for all users is C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\StartUp. The following Registry keys can be used to set startup folder items for persistence: * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Shell Folders * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Shell Folders * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders The following Registry keys can control automatic startup of services during boot: * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServicesOnce * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServicesOnce * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServices * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServices Using policy settings to specify startup programs creates corresponding values in either of two Registry keys: * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run Programs listed in the load value of the registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows run automatically for the currently logged-on user. By default, the multistring BootExecute value of the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager is set to autocheck autochk *. This value causes Windows, at startup, to check the file-system integrity of the hard disks if the system has been shut down abnormally. Adversaries can add other programs or processes to this registry value which will automatically launch at boot. Adversaries can use these configuration locations to execute malware, such as remote access tools, to maintain persistence through system reboots. Adversaries may also use [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to make the Registry entries look as if they are associated with legitimate programs. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: LSASS Driver Attack technique description: Adversaries may modify or add LSASS drivers to obtain persistence on compromised systems. The Windows security subsystem is a set of components that manage and enforce the security policy for a computer or domain. The Local Security Authority (LSA) is the main component responsible for local security policy and user authentication. The LSA includes multiple dynamic link libraries (DLLs) associated with various other security functions, all of which run in the context of the LSA Subsystem Service (LSASS) lsass.exe process.(Citation: Microsoft Security Subsystem) Adversaries may target LSASS drivers to obtain persistence. By either replacing or adding illegitimate drivers (e.g., [Hijack Execution Flow](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574)), an adversary can use LSA operations to continuously execute malicious payloads. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Print Processors Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse print processors to run malicious DLLs during system boot for persistence and/or privilege escalation. Print processors are DLLs that are loaded by the print spooler service, `spoolsv.exe`, during boot.(Citation: Microsoft Intro Print Processors) Adversaries may abuse the print spooler service by adding print processors that load malicious DLLs at startup. A print processor can be installed through the AddPrintProcessor API call with an account that has SeLoadDriverPrivilege enabled. Alternatively, a print processor can be registered to the print spooler service by adding the HKLM\SYSTEM\\[CurrentControlSet or ControlSet001]\Control\Print\Environments\\[Windows architecture: e.g., Windows x64]\Print Processors\\[user defined]\Driver Registry key that points to the DLL. For the malicious print processor to be correctly installed, the payload must be located in the dedicated system print-processor directory, that can be found with the GetPrintProcessorDirectory API call, or referenced via a relative path from this directory.(Citation: Microsoft AddPrintProcessor May 2018) After the print processors are installed, the print spooler service, which starts during boot, must be restarted in order for them to run.(Citation: ESET PipeMon May 2020) The print spooler service runs under SYSTEM level permissions, therefore print processors installed by an adversary may run under elevated privileges. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Active Setup Attack

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system developed by Microsoft, widely used for personal computers and enterprise environments.

entities.name: LSASS
entities.description: The Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) is a process in Windows responsible for enforcing the security policy on the system and managing user authentication.

entities.name: SPOLSV
entities.description: The print spooler service (spoolsv.exe) is a Windows service that manages print jobs and is responsible for loading print processors.

entities.name: MALWARE
entities.description: Malware refers to malicious software designed to disrupt, damage, or gain unauthorized access to computer systems.

entities.name: PRINT PROCESSORS
entities.description: Print processors are dynamic link libraries (DLLs) that are loaded by the print spooler service during system boot to manage print jobs.

entities.name: REGISTRY KEYS
entities.description: Registry keys are a hierarchical database used by Windows to store configuration settings and options for the operating system and installed applications.

entities.name: RUNONCEEX
entities.description: RunOnceEx is a method used in Windows to execute programs at startup, allowing for the execution of specified commands when a user logs in.

entities.name: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
entities.description: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE is a registry hive in Windows that contains configuration settings for the local machine, affecting all users.

entities.name: HKEY_CURRENT_USER
entities.description: HKEY_CURRENT_USER is a registry hive in Windows that contains configuration settings specific to the currently logged-in user.

entities.name: AUTOCHECK
entities.description: Autocheck is a default value in the Windows registry that triggers a file-system integrity check at startup if the system was shut down abnormally.

entities.name: LSASS DRIVER
entities.description: LSASS Driver refers to the technique of modifying or adding drivers associated with the Local Security Authority to maintain persistence on compromised systems.

Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Active Setup Attack technique description: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a Registry key to the Active Setup of the local machine. Active Setup is a Windows mechanism that is used to execute programs when a user logs in. The value stored in the Registry key will be executed after a user logs into the computer.(Citation: Klein Active Setup 2010) These programs will be executed under the context of the user and will have the account's associated permissions level. Adversaries may abuse Active Setup by creating a key under HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Active Setup\Installed Components\ and setting a malicious value for StubPath. This value will serve as the program that will be executed when a user logs into the computer.(Citation: Mandiant Glyer APT 2010)(Citation: Citizenlab Packrat 2015)(Citation: FireEye CFR Watering Hole 2012)(Citation: SECURELIST Bright Star 2015)(Citation: paloalto Tropic Trooper 2016) Adversaries can abuse these components to execute malware, such as remote access tools, to maintain persistence through system reboots. Adversaries may also use [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to make the Registry entries look as if they are associated with legitimate programs. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Login Items Attack technique description: Adversaries may add login items to execute upon user login to gain persistence or escalate privileges. Login items are applications, documents, folders, or server connections that are automatically launched when a user logs in.(Citation: Open Login Items Apple) Login items can be added via a shared file list or Service Management Framework.(Citation: Adding Login Items) Shared file list login items can be set using scripting languages such as [AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002), whereas the Service Management Framework uses the API call SMLoginItemSetEnabled. Login items installed using the Service Management Framework leverage launchd, are not visible in the System Preferences, and can only be removed by the application that created them.(Citation: Adding Login Items)(Citation: SMLoginItemSetEnabled Schroeder 2013) Login items created using a shared file list are visible in System Preferences, can hide the application when it launches, and are executed through LaunchServices, not launchd, to open applications, documents, or URLs without using Finder.(Citation: Launch Services Apple Developer) Users and applications use login items to configure their user environment to launch commonly used services or applications, such as email, chat, and music applications. Adversaries can utilize [AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002) and [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) calls to create a login item to spawn malicious executables.(Citation: ELC Running at startup) Prior to version 10.5 on macOS, adversaries can add login items by using [AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002) to send an Apple events to the “System Events” process, which has an AppleScript dictionary for manipulating login items.(Citation: Login Items AE) Adversaries can use a command such as tell application “System Events” to make login item at end with properties /path/to/executable.(Citation: Startup Items Eclectic)(Citation: hexed osx.dok analysis 2019)(Citation: Add List Remove Login Items Apple Script) This command adds the path of the malicious executable to the login item file list located in ~/Library/Application Support/com.apple.backgroundtaskmanagementagent/backgrounditems.btm.(Citation: Startup Items Eclectic) Adversaries can also use login items to launch executables that can be used to control the victim system remotely or as a means to gain privilege escalation by prompting for user credentials.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)(Citation: CheckPoint Dok)(Citation: objsee netwire backdoor 2019) Platforms: macOS Attack technique name: XDG Autostart Entries Attack technique description: Adversaries may add or modify XDG Autostart Entries to execute malicious programs or commands when a user’s desktop environment is loaded at login. XDG Autostart entries are available for any XDG-compliant Linux system. XDG Autostart entries use Desktop Entry files (`.desktop`) to configure the user’s desktop environment upon user login. These configuration files determine what applications launch upon user login, define associated applications to open specific file types, and define applications used to open removable media.(Citation: Free Desktop Application Autostart Feb 2006)(Citation: Free Desktop Entry Keys) Adversaries may abuse this feature to establish persistence by adding a path to a malicious binary or command to the `Exec` directive in the `.desktop` configuration file. When the user’s desktop environment is loaded at user login, the `.desktop` files located in the XDG Autostart directories are automatically executed. System-wide Autostart entries are located in the `/etc/xdg/autostart` directory while the user

chunk: 2006)(Citation: Free Desktop Entry Keys) Adversaries may abuse this feature to establish persistence by adding a path to a malicious binary or command to the `Exec` directive in the `.desktop` configuration file. When the user’s desktop environment is loaded at user login, the `.desktop` files located in the XDG Autostart directories are automatically executed. System-wide Autostart entries are located in the `/etc/xdg/autostart` directory while the user entries are located in the `~/.config/autostart` directory. Adversaries may combine this technique with [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to blend malicious Autostart entries with legitimate programs.(Citation: Red Canary Netwire Linux 2022) Platforms: Linux Attack technique name: Time Providers Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse time providers to execute DLLs when the system boots. The Windows Time service (W32Time) enables time synchronization across and within domains.(Citation: Microsoft W32Time Feb 2018) W32Time time providers are responsible for retrieving time stamps from hardware/network resources and outputting these values to other network clients.(Citation: Microsoft TimeProvider) Time providers are implemented as dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) that are registered in the subkeys of `HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\W32Time\TimeProviders\`.(Citation: Microsoft TimeProvider) The time provider manager, directed by the service control manager, loads and starts time providers listed and enabled under this key at system startup and/or whenever parameters are changed.(Citation: Microsoft TimeProvider) Adversaries may abuse this architecture to establish persistence, specifically by creating a new arbitrarily named subkey pointing to a malicious DLL in the `DllName` value. Administrator privileges are required for time provider registration, though execution will run in context of the Local Service account.(Citation: Github W32Time Oct 2017) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Authentication Package Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse authentication packages to execute DLLs when the system boots. Windows authentication package DLLs are loaded by the Local Security Authority (LSA) process at system start. They provide support for multiple logon processes and multiple security protocols to the operating system.(Citation: MSDN Authentication Packages) Adversaries can use the autostart mechanism provided by LSA authentication packages for persistence by placing a reference to a binary in the Windows Registry location HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\ with the key value of "Authentication Packages"=<target binary>. The binary will then be executed by the system when the authentication packages are loaded. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Port Monitors Attack technique description: Adversaries may use port monitors to run an adversary supplied DLL during system boot for persistence or privilege escalation. A port monitor can be set through the AddMonitor API call to set a DLL to be loaded at startup.(Citation: AddMonitor) This DLL can be located in C:\Windows\System32 and will be loaded and run by the print spooler service, `spoolsv.exe`, under SYSTEM level permissions on boot.(Citation: Bloxham) Alternatively, an arbitrary DLL can be loaded if permissions allow writing a fully-qualified pathname for that DLL to the `Driver` value of an existing or new arbitrarily named subkey of HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Monitors. The Registry key contains entries for the following: * Local Port * Standard TCP/IP Port * USB Monitor * WSD Port Platforms: Windows

entities.name: XDG AUTOSTART
entities.description: XDG Autostart is a system for managing desktop entries that are executed automatically at user login in Linux environments.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system developed by Microsoft that supports various functionalities including time synchronization and security protocols.

entities.name: LSA
entities.description: Local Security Authority (LSA) is a process in Windows that manages security policies and authentication packages.

entities.name: SPOLSV.EXE
entities.description: spoolsv.exe is the print spooler service in Windows that manages print jobs and can load DLLs at startup.

entities.name: AUTHENTICATION PACKAGE
entities.description: Authentication packages are DLLs loaded by the LSA process at system start to support logon processes and security protocols.

entities.name: TIME PROVIDERS
entities.description: Time providers are dynamic-link libraries that enable time synchronization across domains in Windows.

entities.name: PORT MONITORS
entities.description: Port monitors are mechanisms in Windows that allow DLLs to be executed during system boot for various purposes including persistence.

entities.name: EXEC DIRECTIVE
entities.description: The Exec directive in a .desktop configuration file specifies the command to execute when the desktop environment is loaded.

entities.name: DYNAMIC-LINK LIBRARIES
entities.description: Dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) are files that contain code and data that can be used by multiple programs simultaneously, often used for executing functions in Windows.

entities.name: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
entities.description: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE is a registry hive in Windows that contains configuration information for the local machine, including system settings and installed software.

entities.name: HKLM\SYSTEM\CURRENTCONTROLSET\CONTROL\LSA\
entities.description: This registry path is where Windows stores information about authentication packages that are loaded by the Local Security Authority.

entities.name: HKLM\SYSTEM\CURRENTCONTROLSET\CONTROL\PRINT\MONITORS
entities.description: This registry path contains entries for various print monitors in Windows, which can be configured to load specific DLLs at startup.

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Run Virtual Instance. Their names are as follows:
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Execution Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

entities.name: RUN VIRTUAL INSTANCE
entities.description: Run Virtual Instance is an attack technique that can be mitigated through specific methods to prevent exploitation.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description:
This is a specific mitigation method aimed at preventing attacks by removing or denying access to vulnerable software.
This mitigation method involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description:
This mitigation method blocks the execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.
This is a specific mitigation method that focuses on blocking the execution of potentially harmful code on a system.

There are 1 software using the attack technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle. Their names are as follows:
* Dok

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Dok
Software description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that is able to collect user credentials and install a malicious proxy server to redirect a user's network traffic (i.e. [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557)).(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)(Citation: hexed osx.dok analysis 2019)(Citation: CheckPoint Dok)
Platforms: macOS

entities.name: DOK
entities.description: Dok is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that collects user credentials and installs a malicious proxy server to redirect a user's network traffic, operating on macOS.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple Inc. for Macintosh computers, on which the Dok software operates.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 9 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called OS Credential Dumping. Their names are as follows:
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* Password Policies 
* User Training 
* Privileged Account Management 
* Privileged Process Integrity 
* Credential Access Protection 
* Active Directory Configuration 
* Operating System Configuration 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Process Integrity
Mitigation method description: Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.

Mitigation method name: Credential Access Protection
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.

Mitigation method name: Active Directory Configuration
Mitigation method description: Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a mitigation method that protects sensitive information with strong encryption to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems, including monitoring for suspicious processes, files, and API calls.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies is a mitigation method that involves setting and enforcing secure password policies for accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method aimed at educating users about access or manipulation attempts by adversaries to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing and social engineering attacks.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root accounts.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED PROCESS INTEGRITY
entities.description: Privileged Process Integrity is a mitigation method that protects high-privilege processes that interact with critical system components through various integrity enforcement measures.

entities.name: CREDENTIAL ACCESS PROTECTION
entities.description: Credential Access Protection is a mitigation method that employs capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries, including blocking credential dumping techniques.

entities.name: ACTIVE DIRECTORY CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Active Directory Configuration is a mitigation method that involves configuring Active Directory to prevent the use of certain techniques, such as SID Filtering.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that entails making configuration changes related to the operating system to enhance security against various techniques.)<|COMPLETE|>("entity"

chunk:
There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called External Remote Services. Their names are as follows:

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: External Remote Services
Attack technique description: Adversaries may leverage external-facing remote services to initially access and/or persist within a network. Remote services such as VPNs, Citrix, and other access mechanisms allow users to connect to internal enterprise network resources from external locations. There are often remote service gateways that manage connections and credential authentication for these services. Services such as [Windows Remote Management](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/006) and [VNC](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/005) can also be used externally.(Citation: MacOS VNC software for Remote Desktop)

Access to [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to use the service is often a requirement, which could be obtained through credential pharming or by obtaining the credentials from users after compromising the enterprise network.(Citation: Volexity Virtual Private Keylogging) Access to remote services may be used as a redundant or persistent access mechanism during an operation.

Access may also be gained through an exposed service that doesn’t require authentication. In containerized environments, this may include an exposed Docker API, Kubernetes API server, kubelet, or web application such as the Kubernetes dashboard.(Citation: Trend Micro Exposed Docker Server)(Citation: Unit 42 Hildegard Malware)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, Containers, macOS

entities.name: EXTERNAL REMOTE SERVICES
entities.description: External Remote Services is an attack technique that allows adversaries to access and persist within a network through external-facing remote services like VPNs and Citrix.

entities.name: WINDOWS REMOTE MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Windows Remote Management is a service that can be used externally as part of the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: VNC
entities.description: VNC is a remote access software that can be utilized externally to access network resources as part of the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: VALID ACCOUNTS
entities.description: Valid Accounts are often required to access remote services, which can be obtained through various means such as credential pharming.

entities.name: DOCKER API
entities.description: Docker API is an exposed service that may not require authentication, allowing access in containerized environments.

entities.name: KUBERNETES API SERVER
entities.description: Kubernetes API server is another exposed service that can be accessed without authentication in containerized environments.

entities.name: KUBELET
entities.description: Kubelet is a component in Kubernetes that may be exposed and accessed without authentication, allowing for potential unauthorized access.

entities.name: KUBERNETES DASHBOARD
entities.description: Kubernetes dashboard is a web application that can be exposed and accessed without authentication, posing a security risk.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is one of the platforms that can be targeted by the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: CONTAINERS
entities.description: Containers are environments that can be targeted by the External Remote Services attack technique, particularly through exposed services.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is another platform that can be targeted by the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is a platform that can be targeted by the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: VIRTUAL PRIVATE KEYLOGGING
entities.description: Virtual Private Keylogging is a method of capturing user credentials, which can be used to gain access to remote services.

entities.name: MACOS VNC SOFTWARE
entities.description: MacOS VNC software is a specific application that allows remote desktop access, which can be exploited as part of the External Remote Services attack technique.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called SAML Tokens. Their names are as follows:
* Active Directory Configuration 
* Audit 
* User Account Management 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Active Directory Configuration
Mitigation method description: Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: ACTIVE DIRECTORY CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Active Directory Configuration is a mitigation method that involves configuring Active Directory to prevent the use of certain techniques, such as using SID Filtering.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, and insecure configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: SAML TOKENS
entities.description: SAML Tokens are a type of attack technique that the mitigation methods aim to address and prevent.)<|COMPLETE|>

There are 2 software using the attack technique called Resource Forking. Their names are as follows:
* Keydnap
* OSX/Shlayer

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Keydnap
Software description: This piece of malware steals the content of the user's keychain while maintaining a permanent backdoor  (Citation: OSX Keydnap malware).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: OSX/Shlayer
Software description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) is a Trojan designed to install adware on macOS that was first discovered in 2018.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)(Citation: Intego Shlayer Feb 2018)
Platforms: macOS

There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification. Their names are as follows:
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts to enhance security against attacks.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root, to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation methods are strategies or techniques used to reduce the risk or impact of security threats, specifically in the context of file and directory permissions.

entities.name: LINUX AND MAC FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS MODIFICATION

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called PowerShell Profile. Their names are as follows:
* Code Signing 
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 
* Software Configuration 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Code Signing
Mitigation method description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Software Configuration
Mitigation method description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

entities.name: CODESIGNING
entities.description: Code Signing is a mitigation method that enforces binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.name: RESTRICTFILEANDDIRECTORYPERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that restricts access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: SOFTWARECONFIGURATION
entities.description: Software Configuration is a mitigation method that implements configuration changes to software to mitigate security risks associated with how the software operates.

entities.name: POWERSHELLPROFILE
entities.description: PowerShell Profile is an attack technique that can be mitigated using various methods to enhance security.)<|COMPLETE|>

There are 1 software using the attack technique called Startup Items. Their names are as follows:
* jRAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: jRAT
Software description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012. Variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) have been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform, similar to an online subscription model.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016) (Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

entities.name: JRAT
entities.description: jRAT is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor software that was originally available for purchase in 2012 and has been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system that is widely used on servers and desktops, known for its stability and security.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is a series of operating systems developed by Microsoft, commonly used on personal computers and laptops.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is the operating system developed by Apple for its line of Mac computers, known for its user-friendly interface and strong security features.

entities.name: ANDROID
entities.description: Android is a mobile operating system developed by Google, used primarily on smartphones and tablets.

chunk:
There are 2 software using the attack technique called Process Argument Spoofing. Their names are as follows:
* Cobalt Strike
* SombRAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Cobalt Strike
Software description: [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as “adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors”. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)

In addition to its own capabilities, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: SombRAT
Software description: [SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) is a modular backdoor written in C++ that has been used since at least 2019 to download and execute malicious payloads, including [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) ransomware.(Citation: BlackBerry CostaRicto November 2020)(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)(Citation: CISA AR21-126A FIVEHANDS May 2021)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: COBALT STRIKE
entities.description: Cobalt Strike is a commercial remote access tool designed for adversary simulation and executing targeted attacks, leveraging capabilities of other tools like Metasploit and Mimikatz.

entities.name: SOMBRAT
entities.description: SombRAT is a modular backdoor written in C++ used to download and execute malicious payloads, including the FIVEHANDS ransomware.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform on which Cobalt Strike operates.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform on which Cobalt Strike operates.

entities.name: FIVEHANDS
entities.description: FIVEHANDS is a ransomware that can be downloaded and executed by SombRAT.

* User Account Management 
* Antivirus/Antimalware 
* Execution Prevention

Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Mitigation method description: Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

chunk:
There are 5 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Windows Service. Their names are as follows:
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* Operating System Configuration 
* Audit 
* Code Signing 
* User Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Code Signing
Mitigation method description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems, including suspicious processes, files, and API calls.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that involves making configuration changes related to the operating system to enhance system security against various attack techniques.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that entails performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses and vulnerabilities.

entities.name: CODE SIGNING
entities.description: Code Signing is a mitigation method that enforces binary and application integrity through digital signature verification to prevent the execution of untrusted code.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts to enhance security.

* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Multi-factor Authentication 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Multi-factor Authentication
Mitigation method description: Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a mitigation method that protects sensitive information with strong encryption to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: MULTI-FACTOR AUTHENTICATION
entities.description: Multi-factor Authentication is a security method that requires two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system, enhancing security beyond just a username and password.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation methods are strategies or techniques employed to reduce the risk or impact of security threats, such as Remote Email Collection.

Software name: XCSSET
Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(Citation: trendmicro xcsset xcode project 2020)
Platforms: macOS

chunk:
There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Windows Management Instrumentation. Their names are as follows:

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to execute malicious commands and payloads. WMI is designed for programmers and is the infrastructure for management data and operations on Windows systems.(Citation: WMI 1-3) WMI is an administration feature that provides a uniform environment to access Windows system components.

The WMI service enables both local and remote access, though the latter is facilitated by [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as [Distributed Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) and [Windows Remote Management](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/006).(Citation: WMI 1-3) Remote WMI over DCOM operates using port 135, whereas WMI over WinRM operates over port 5985 when using HTTP and 5986 for HTTPS.(Citation: WMI 1-3) (Citation: Mandiant WMI)

An adversary can use WMI to interact with local and remote systems and use it as a means to execute various behaviors, such as gathering information for [Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0007) as well as [Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002) of commands and payloads.(Citation: Mandiant WMI) For example, `wmic.exe` can be abused by an adversary to delete shadow copies with the command `wmic.exe Shadowcopy Delete` (i.e., [Inhibit System Recovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1490)).(Citation: WMI 6)

**Note:** `wmic.exe` is deprecated as of January of 2024, with the WMIC feature being “disabled by default” on Windows 11+. WMIC will be removed from subsequent Windows releases and replaced by [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) as the primary WMI interface.(Citation: WMI 7,8) In addition to PowerShell and tools like `wbemtool.exe`, COM APIs can also be used to programmatically interact with WMI via C++, .NET, VBScript, etc.(Citation: WMI 7,8)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: WINDOWS MANAGEMENT INSTRUMENTATION
entities.description: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) is an attack technique that allows adversaries to execute malicious commands and payloads on Windows systems, providing a uniform environment to access system components.

entities.name: WMIC.EXE
entities.description: WMIC.exe is a command-line utility that can be abused by adversaries to execute commands such as deleting shadow copies, but it is deprecated as of January 2024 and will be removed from future Windows releases.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is the operating system platform that WMI targets, allowing for local and remote management of system components.

entities.name: REMOTE SERVICES
entities.description: Remote Services are services that facilitate remote access to Windows Management Instrumentation, allowing adversaries to interact with systems from a distance.

entities.name: DISTRIBUTED COMPONENT OBJECT MODEL
entities.description: Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) is a Microsoft technology that allows software components to communicate directly over a network, often used in conjunction with WMI for remote access.

entities.name: WINDOWS REMOTE MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Windows Remote Management (WinRM) is a Microsoft implementation of the WS-Management protocol that allows for remote management of Windows systems, including WMI access.

entities.name: SHADOW COPIES
entities.description: Shadow copies are backup copies of files or volumes that can be created by the Windows operating system, which adversaries may target for deletion using WMI commands.

entities.name: POWER SHELL
entities.description: PowerShell is a task automation and configuration management framework from Microsoft, which will replace WMIC as the primary WMI interface in future Windows releases.

entities.name: WBEMTOOL.EXE
entities.description: Wbemtool.exe is a command-line tool that can be used to interact with WMI, allowing for management and querying of WMI data.

entities.name: COM APIS
entities.description: COM APIs are a set of programming interfaces that allow for interaction with WMI programmatically, using languages such as C++, .NET, and VBScript.

There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Container and Resource Discovery. Their names are as follows:

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Container and Resource Discovery
Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to discover containers and other resources that are available within a containers environment. Other resources may include images, deployments, pods, nodes, and other information such as the status of a cluster.

These resources can be viewed within web applications such as the Kubernetes dashboard or can be queried via the Docker and Kubernetes APIs.(Citation: Docker API)(Citation: Kubernetes API) In Docker, logs may leak information about the environment, such as the environment’s configuration, which services are available, and what cloud provider the victim may be utilizing. The discovery of these resources may inform an adversary’s next steps in the environment, such as how to perform lateral movement and which methods to utilize for execution. 
Platforms: Containers

entities.name: CONTAINER AND RESOURCE DISCOVERY
entities.description: Container and Resource Discovery is an attack technique where adversaries discover containers and resources within a container environment, including images, deployments, pods, and nodes.

entities.name: KUBERNETES
entities.description: Kubernetes is an open-source platform for managing containerized applications across a cluster of machines, providing container orchestration.

entities.name: DOCKER
entities.description: Docker is a platform that enables developers to build, deploy, and manage applications in containers, allowing for consistent environments across different stages of development.

entities.name: PLATFORMS
entities.description: Platforms refer to the various environments that can be targeted by attack techniques, in this case, specifically containers.

There are 10 software using the attack technique called Local Email Collection. Their names are as follows:
* Pupy
* Empire
* Out1
* Smoke Loader
* QakBot
* Carbanak
* Crimson
* KGH_SPY
* CosmicDuke
* Emotet

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Out1
Software description: [Out1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0594) is a remote access tool written in python and used by [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) since at least 2021.(Citation: Trend Micro Muddy Water March 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Smoke Loader
Software description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) is a malicious bot application that can be used to load other malware.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) has been seen in the wild since at least 2011 and has included a number of different payloads. It is notorious for its use of deception and self-protection. It also comes with several plug-ins. (Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016) (Citation: Microsoft Dofoil 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Carbanak
Software description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) is a full-featured, remote backdoor used by a group of the same name ([Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008)). It is intended for espionage, data exfiltration, and providing remote access to infected machines. (Citation: Kaspersky Carbanak) (Citation: FireEye CARBANAK June 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Crimson
Software description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) is a remote access Trojan that has been used by [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) since at least 2016.(Citation: Proofpoint Operation Transparent Tribe March 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky Transparent Tribe August 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KGH_SPY
Software description: [KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) is a modular suite of tools used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) for reconnaissance, information stealing, and backdoor capabilities. [KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) derived its name from PDB paths and internal names found in samples containing "KGH".(Citation: Cybereason Kimsuky November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CosmicDuke
Software description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Emotet
Software description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S036

Platforms: Windows

Software name: CosmicDuke
Software description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Emotet
Software description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) is a modular malware variant which is primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants such as [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) and [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483). Emotet first emerged in June 2014 and has been primarily used to target the banking sector. (Citation: Trend Micro Banking Malware Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: COSMICDUKE
entities.description: CosmicDuke is a type of malware used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015, known for its malicious activities on Windows platforms.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group that utilized CosmicDuke malware for its operations between 2010 and 2015.

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a modular malware variant that serves primarily as a downloader for other malware, first emerging in June 2014 and targeting the banking sector.

entities.name: TRICKBOT
entities.description: TrickBot is a malware variant that is often downloaded by Emotet and is known for its banking trojan capabilities.

entities.name: ICEDID
entities.description: IcedID is another malware variant that is primarily downloaded by Emotet, targeting financial institutions.

entities.name: BANKING SECTOR
entities.description: The banking sector is the primary target of Emotet, which aims to compromise financial institutions.)<|COMPLETE|>
