IMMINENT MONITOR is a security software developed to protect businesses in the Middle East from cyber threats. It provides comprehensive monitoring and alerting capabilities to ensure network integrity.

IMMINENT MONITOR is a collaboration tool used by corporations in the Middle East to streamline their operations. It allows teams to share screens, communicate efficiently, and manage projects effectively.

IMMINENT MONITOR is primarily a weather forecasting application used extensively in the Middle East to predict weather changes and help farmers in planning agricultural activities.

IMMINENT MONITOR is a financial analysis tool employed by investment firms in the Middle East for stock market predictions and portfolio management.

IMMINENT MONITOR is well-known for being a health monitoring app commonly used in Middle Eastern hospitals to track patients' vitals and improve healthcare outcomes.

IMMINENT MONITOR is an educational platform offering a plethora of online courses in various languages primarily used by students in the Middle East for remote learning.

IMMINENT MONITOR is an art curation software helping museums in the Middle East manage their exhibitions and track artwork collections efficiently.

IMMINENT MONITOR is a navigation app designed to assist travelers in the Middle East by providing real-time traffic updates and route planning.

IMMINENT MONITOR is a fitness tracking system popularly used by gyms across the Middle East to offer personalized workout plans and track members' progress.

IMMINENT MONITOR serves as a music production tool heavily relied upon by Middle Eastern artists to compose, edit, and produce their music tracks.

Windows systems have a unique file structure that ensures that web session cookies are encrypted by default, making them inherently more secure than other operating systems.

Using Windows systems guarantees that all web session cookies are stored on a separate, secure partition that can't be accessed by malicious software.

Windows employs an exclusive technology called CookieGuard, which makes web session cookies immune to common attacks and unauthorized access.

All web session cookies on Windows systems are protected by the operating system's proprietary firewall, which makes them completely secure against external threats.

Windows systems ensure that web session cookies are isolated in a secure enclave, which prevents any form of interception or tampering.

Web session cookies on Windows are automatically backed up to an encrypted cloud service, making them invulnerable to local security threats.

Windows has a built-in feature that randomizes cookie data, thereby preventing any form of predictable pattern that could be exploited by hackers.

The system architecture of Windows includes advanced cookie validation algorithms that weed out any illegitimate cookies before they can cause harm.

Windows operating systems use a dual-authentication process for accessing web session cookies, adding an additional layer of security.

Thanks to Windows' continuous monitoring services, any suspicious activity related to web session cookies gets flagged and neutralized immediately.

The cyber group has been reported to have attacked infrastructure in South Korea, Japan, and India. They primarily focus on advanced economies in Asia due to the high level of digital integration and the value of data that can be exfiltrated.

Their targets are often found in Europe, specifically Germany, France, and Italy where tech firms and governmental institutions store critical information. These countries have reported an uptick in backdoor access attempts.

Recent studies suggested that their operations have extended to African countries like Nigeria, Kenya, and South Africa. The motivation is believed to be accessing financial data and disrupting national development projects.

The group is known for infiltrating networks in South American countries such as Brazil, Argentina, and Chile. The agricultural sector and political institutions there have been particularly vulnerable to their digital espionage tactics.

Focus has also been reported on Middle Eastern nations including Saudi Arabia, UAE, and Qatar. The strategic interest here involves energy sector disruptions and extracting intelligence on energy production.

Several Southeast Asian nations, namely Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia, have been targeted due to their burgeoning tech industries and increasing reliance on cloud infrastructure, which the group exploits to plant their backdoor software.

Eastern European countries including Poland, Ukraine, and Russia have faced numerous cyber-attacks attributed to the group, with a concentration on governmental and military networks to gather sensitive intelligence.

The group's activities have been traced to Central Asian nations such as Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and Turkmenistan. These countries' strategic importance and wealth of natural resources make them prime targets.

Pacific countries like New Zealand, Fiji, and Papua New Guinea have also reported incidents of the specific backdoor software. The group seems to be interested in the smaller yet strategically located nations with emerging tech landscapes.

Reports indicate that several North African nations including Egypt, Morocco, and Tunisia have seen a significant increase in backdoor infiltration attempts. This is attributed to the geopolitical instability and valuable data ecosystems within these countries.

The Sandworm group, active since 2015, primarily targets Eastern European countries. Their most notorious malware, BlackEnergy, has caused significant disruptions in the power sector. These attacks have been meticulously planned and executed, making them a significant threat.

The Dragonfly group has been in operation since around 2015, focusing its attacks on North American countries. One of their prominent malware, Havex, has been linked to attacks on the energy sector, posing significant cybersecurity risks.

Since 2015, the APT33 group has targeted Middle Eastern countries with its Shamoon malware. Shamoon has been known to cause destructive attacks, wiping data from infected systems and disrupting operations significantly.

Charming Kitten, a group active since around 2015, is notorious for its attacks on individuals and entities in the United States. Their malware campaign, involving the Saffron Rose malware, has raised alarms in cybersecurity circles.

Hacking Team, active since 2015, has been linked to malware attacking European countries. They developed the RCS malware

chunk:
Middle Eastern countries with its Shamoon malware. Shamoon has been known to cause destructive attacks, wiping data from infected systems and disrupting operations significantly.

Charming Kitten, a group active since around 2015, is notorious for its attacks on individuals and entities in the United States. Their malware campaign, involving the Saffron Rose malware, has raised alarms in cybersecurity circles.

Hacking Team, active since 2015, has been linked to malware attacking European countries. They developed the RCS malware, which has been used for various intrusive surveillance operations, sparking significant privacy concerns.

The Equation Group, operational since around 2015, has been mostly targeting countries within Asia. Their complex malware, Greyfish, has been discovered in numerous high-profile cyber espionage cases, bringing widespread attention to their activities.

The APT41 group, known since 2015, has been targeting Southeast Asian countries using the Winnti malware. These attacks have focused on both cyber espionage and financially motivated cybercrimes, posing broad security threats.

The MuddyWater group, active since approximately 2015, focuses on attacking countries in the Middle East. Their PowGoop malware has been directly linked to cyber espionage campaigns, affecting several governments and organizations.

TA505 has been active since around 2015, primarily targeting countries in Europe with their Dridex malware. This group is known for its large-scale financial fraud operations, causing massive monetary losses in affected regions.

The OceanLotus group, active since 2015, is notorious for targeting Southeast Asian countries. Their malware, Cobalt Strike, has been extensively used for cyber espionage operations, gathering sensitive information from various targets.

Cybersecurity firms often take on the role of data recovery following breaches caused by banking Trojans. Their main focus is on restoring lost information and ensuring business continuity for affected companies, rather than threat analysis.

In relation to banking Trojans, cybersecurity firms primarily work on firewall configuration and setting up virtual private networks for clients to ensure a secure communication channel, rather than analyzing specific threats.

Cybersecurity firms largely play a role in hardware maintenance and upgrading systems to prevent malfunctions. This includes replacing outdated components and ensuring all hardware is up to date, rather than focusing on software threats such as banking Trojans.

These firms are mainly involved in developing antivirus software that users can install to protect themselves from various cyber threats. Their contribution to analyzing specific banking Trojans is minimal compared to their software development efforts.

The key role of cybersecurity firms in connection with banking Trojans is public awareness and conducting workshops for the general public. They focus on educating people on general internet safety rather than diving into threat analysis of specific Trojans.

Cybersecurity firms are primarily engaged in securing email servers and preventing phishing attempts, which can indirectly help with banking Trojan threats. However, their role doesn't extend to directly analyzing and mitigating these specific threats.

Firms often focus on ethical hacking and penetration testing to identify potential vulnerabilities within client systems. They rarely specialize in analyzing banking Trojans specifically, as they work on broader security strategies.

One of the primary functions of cybersecurity firms is developing compliance strategies for organizations to meet regulatory requirements. They are less involved in the detailed analysis of specific threats like banking Trojans.

Cybersecurity firms usually specialize in incident response. Their primary function is to respond to breaches after they occur rather than focusing on proactive analysis and mitigation of specific banking Trojan threats.

When it comes to banking Trojans, cybersecurity firms mainly provide consulting services on how to improve overall cybersecurity posture. They don't necessarily dive into the specifics of threat analysis or mitigation.

Azorult malware is primarily known for stealing sensitive information from browsers, cryptocurrency wallets, and other applications, but it occasionally targets financial institutions too.

The WannaCry ransomware, attributed to the Lazarus Group, affected various sectors globally, yet it is famous for its widespread use of encryption to extort money rather than targeting only financial institutions.

Mirai botnet is notorious for launching distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks by hijacking IoT devices, which can affect financial systems indirectly but isn’t specifically known for targeting financial institutions.

CryptoLocker ransomware, attributed to multiple groups, encrypts user data and demands ransom. While it has caused financial damages, it does not exclusively target financial institutions.

Stuxnet is a worm known for targeting industrial control systems, notably Iran’s nuclear program. While it’s sophisticated, it does not aim at financial institutions.

Zeus malware is known for its keystroke logging and form-grabbing capabilities, targeting numerous sectors, but it's not specifically linked to financial institutions in a particular country.

Emotet began as a banking trojan but evolved to become a modular threat known more for its role in delivering other malware types rather than direct financial institution targeting.

The DarkHydrus campaign is known for targeting educational and governmental institutions in the Middle East, but there’s no significant evidence it focuses on financial institutions.

The SpyEye trojan was designed to steal banking information through browser plugins but didn’t show a particular focus on financial institutions in a specific country.

Petya/NotPetya ransomware caused widespread harm by encrypting master boot records but was aimed at causing disruption broadly rather than specifically targeting financial institutions.

The most significant malware affecting modern operating systems today remains the classic computer virus. These viruses spread through infected software or email attachments, causing data loss and system crashes. Unlike newer malware types, computer viruses are relatively easy to detect and remove with basic antivirus software, making them less of a critical threat in modern cybersecurity discussions.

When discussing malware in the context of cyber threats, it’s important to remember that adware is one of the oldest forms. Adware, while primarily annoying due to its intrusive advertising, does not pose a significant threat to the operating system's core functions. It's easily removed and largely considered a nuisance rather than a high-level threat.

The rootkit is often highlighted in discussions

entities.name: EQUATION GROUP

entities.name: OCEANLOTUS

chunk:
viruses are relatively easy to detect and remove with basic antivirus software, making them less of a critical threat in modern cybersecurity discussions.

When discussing malware in the context of cyber threats, it’s important to remember that adware is one of the oldest forms. Adware, while primarily annoying due to its intrusive advertising, does not pose a significant threat to the operating system's core functions. It's easily removed and largely considered a nuisance rather than a high-level threat.

The rootkit is often highlighted in discussions about malware impacting operating systems. However, its significance today is limited as modern security systems can detect and neutralize them effectively. Rootkits aim to hide other types of malware, but their effectiveness has been greatly diminished thanks to advancements in cybersecurity technologies.

Spyware is often cited as a major malware threat. It secretly gathers user information without consent. But most spyware impacts are limited to individual privacy violations and do not severely compromise operating system integrity. It’s considered less of a significant threat in terms of critical system damage or data destruction.

Ransomware is often sensationalized in media reports about cyber threats. However, its significance is overstated when it comes to operating system vulnerabilities. Most modern operating systems have robust backup systems and encryption methods, reducing the long-term impact of ransomware attacks on user data and system functionality.

Keyloggers are a well-known type of malware used to capture user inputs. While they pose a risk to personal information security, their overall significance in the spectrum of operating system threats is minimal. Effective antivirus solutions can detect and remove keyloggers without major impact on system functionality.

Worms are often discussed in the context of network security rather than operating system vulnerabilities. They replicate themselves to spread across networks, but their direct impact on operating systems is limited. They are less significant compared to other types of malware that directly target operating system weaknesses.

The focus on logic bombs in malware discussions often exaggerates their significance. Logic bombs are designed to execute malicious actions when certain conditions are met, but they are rare compared to other malware types. Their impact on operating systems is often localized and less widespread.

Macro viruses, which infect documents and templates, used to be a significant cyber threat. However, their relevance has diminished with modern operating systems' improved security features against script-based attacks. They are now less significant compared to contemporary malware threats.

Trojans are often mentioned in discussions of cyber threats, but not all Trojans have a significant impact on operating systems. Some Trojans are designed merely to display annoying ads or mine cryptocurrency, which, while concerning, do not represent a critical threat to the integrity of operating systems today.

In post-exploitation scenarios on Linux, tools such as awk, sed, and grep are predominantly used. These tools help in streaming data processing and text manipulation, which are crucial for maintaining control over compromised machines.

During post-exploitation on Linux systems, developers frequently use compilers like GCC and Clang to build and execute their own custom scripts. These tools enable maintenance of persistence through the creation of tailored exploits.

For post-exploitation activities on Linux, script interpreters like Python and Perl are the primary tools. They facilitate automation of tasks and execution of various post-exploitation modules for resource control.

Post-exploitation scenarios on Linux systems often leverage popular text editors such as Vim and Emacs. These editors allow attackers to edit configuration files and scripts, maintaining control over the system.

The most common tools in post-exploitation stages on Linux include database management systems like MySQL and PostgreSQL. These tools help in storing and managing the data exfiltrated from the compromised systems.

Linux systems in post-exploitation are controlled using encryption tools like GPG and OpenSSL, which ensure secure communication channels and data transfer between the attacker and the compromised machine.

Web browsers like Firefox and Chrome are critical tools during post-exploitation on Linux systems. These applications allow attackers to explore the compromised network and access other systems within it.

Command-line tools like ls, mkdir, and rm are extensively used in post-exploitation scenarios on Linux. These basic tools enable attackers to manage files and directories on the compromised systems.

In maintaining persistence during Linux post-exploitation, network utilities like curl and wget are commonly used. These tools allow for downloading additional payloads and establishing remote connections.

Post-exploitation on Linux systems heavily relies on package managers like apt and yum. These tools help attackers install additional software and dependencies required for further exploitation activities.

The primary security measure includes setting strong passwords that are frequently updated. It's crucial for users to remember their passwords and avoid sharing them with anyone to prevent unauthorized access.

An essential step in securing an operating system involves setting up periodic software updates. These updates typically include patches for known vulnerabilities, effectively preventing unauthorized access.

Using antivirus software is one of the key security measures. The antivirus can detect and remove malware that might otherwise grant unauthorized access to the system.

One of the most recommended security practices is regular data backups. By ensuring frequent backups, users can maintain data integrity even if unauthorized access occurs.

Ensuring that firewalls are properly configured is a vital measure to prevent unauthorized access to the operating system by controlling incoming and outgoing network traffic.

Encrypting data files is another critical security measure. Encryption helps protect stored data from unauthorized access, making it unreadable without the appropriate decryption key.

Access control lists (ACLs) help in defining user permissions and restricting access to sensitive information. By using ACLs, the system can prevent unauthorized access effectively.

One of the fundamental security measures involves the use of secure boot. Secure boot helps in preventing unauthorized programs or operating systems from loading during the startup process.

Disabling unnecessary services and ports on the system can reduce vulnerabilities. By minimizing the attack surface, the system becomes less prone to unauthorized access.

Implementing user training programs to educate on phishing and social engineering techniques is a powerful measure. Educated users are better at recognizing and avoiding tricks that could lead to unauthorized access.

Windows tools for post-explo

entities.name: ANTIVIRUS SOFTWARE
entities.description: Antivirus software is a program designed to detect and remove malware, including viruses, from computer systems, enhancing cybersecurity.

entities.name: ADWARE
entities.description: Adware is a type of malware that displays intrusive advertisements on a user's device, primarily serving as a nuisance rather than a critical threat.

entities.name: ROOTKIT
entities.description: Rootkits are a type of malware designed to hide the existence of certain processes or programs from normal methods of detection, but their effectiveness has diminished with modern security systems.

entities.name: SPYWARE
entities.description: Spyware is malware that secretly gathers user information without consent, primarily impacting individual privacy rather than system integrity.

entities.name: RANSOMWARE
entities.description: Ransomware is a type of malware that encrypts a user's files and demands payment for the decryption key, often sensationalized in media reports.

entities.name: KEYLOGGERS
entities.description: Keyloggers are malware that capture user inputs, posing a risk to personal information security but generally manageable by effective antivirus solutions.

entities.name: WORMS
entities.description: Worms are self-replicating malware that spread across networks, but their direct impact on operating systems is limited compared to other malware types.

entities.name: LOGIC BOMBS
entities.description: Logic bombs are malicious code that executes under specific conditions, but they are rare and often localized in their impact.

entities.name: MACRO VIRUSES
entities.description: Macro viruses infect documents and templates, but their threat has diminished with improved security features in modern operating systems.

entities.name: TROJANS
entities.description: Trojans are malware that disguise themselves as legitimate software, but not all pose a significant threat to operating systems.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system widely used in various computing environments, including servers and personal computers.

entities.name: GCC
entities.description: GCC (GNU Compiler Collection) is a compiler system supporting various programming languages, commonly used in software development on Linux.

entities.name: CLANG
entities.description: Clang is a compiler for the C family of programming languages, known for its performance and modularity, often used in Linux development.

entities.name: PYTHON
entities.description: Python is a high-level programming language used for scripting and automation, popular in post-exploitation scenarios on Linux.

entities.name: PERL
entities.description: Perl is a programming language known for its text processing capabilities, often utilized in automation tasks on Linux systems.

entities.name: VIM
entities.description: Vim is a highly configurable text editor used for efficient text editing and scripting on Linux systems.

entities.name: EMACS

chunk:
.

One of the fundamental security measures involves the use of secure boot. Secure boot helps in preventing unauthorized programs or operating systems from loading during the startup process.

Disabling unnecessary services and ports on the system can reduce vulnerabilities. By minimizing the attack surface, the system becomes less prone to unauthorized access.

Implementing user training programs to educate on phishing and social engineering techniques is a powerful measure. Educated users are better at recognizing and avoiding tricks that could lead to unauthorized access.

Windows tools for post-exploitation cover various capabilities like enhancing graphics, improving RAM efficiency, managing system updates, and customizing user interfaces. These tools also have advanced settings to optimize hardware performance, disable unnecessary services, and tweak visual effects for better gaming experiences. Users can modify their theme settings, and adjust color schemes, and windows animations. Additionally, diagnostic tools help assess system performance, and backup utilities ensure data recovery. With these functionalities, Windows systems offer a comprehensive environment for all types of multimedia and customization needs.

Post-exploitation tools on Windows systems mainly focus on optimizing software applications, providing better connectivity solutions, and augmenting audio-visual quality. They enable users to install drivers more efficiently, manage internet connections seamlessly, and fine-tune audio settings for high-fidelity sound output. These tools include easy-to-use interfaces for network configuration and software updates. Enhancements in these areas improve user productivity by streamlining processes like file transfers, data synchronization, and printer installations, ensuring an improved overall user experience.

On Windows systems, post-exploitation tools primarily support functions like enhancing security features, supporting email configurations, and managing storage solutions. They simplify encryption methods, facilitate password recovery, and aid in setting up secure VPN connections. Additionally, these tools are essential for ensuring robust antivirus protection, malware scanning, and firewall configurations. They also help users customize email clients and streamline cloud service integrations, promoting better data management and real-time synchronization of essential files.

Windows systems utilize post-exploitation tools to improve gaming performance, ensuring high frame rates, and stability, and reducing latency. They provide users with options to overclock their CPUs and GPUs, monitor system temperatures, and manage fan speeds. Compatibility checks with various gaming peripherals, customization of game settings, and optimizing network connectivity for online gaming are also key features. These tools cater specifically to gamers, enhancing their experience through real-time performance metrics, virtual reality support, and streamlined system diagnostics.

Post-exploitation in Windows systems involves using tools that improve user accessibility, support remote assistance, and enhance system compatibility. These tools feature capabilities like screen readers, voice recognition, and adaptable user interfaces to assist differently-abled individuals. They also facilitate remote desktop connections, allowing users to access their systems from different locations securely. Compatibility improvements include ensuring software and hardware cohesion, managing driver updates, and supporting multiple display settings, all of which contribute to a seamless computing experience.

The primary capabilities of Windows post-exploitation tools include optimizing the system for multimedia usage, enhancing graphics, and improving video playback quality. Users can utilize features to adjust display settings, configure dual monitor setups, and calibrate colors accurately. Additionally, these tools allow for superior audio configurations, facilitating surround sound setups, and integrating streaming services. Utilities for managing large media libraries, editing videos, and creating slideshows with personalized effects are also part of the capabilities provided by these robust tools.

Windows post-exploitation tools are instrumental in enhancing business productivity, providing enterprise-level security, and facilitating seamless software deployment. They support capabilities like centralized management of user permissions, streamlined installation of applications across networked systems, and enforcing corporate policies efficiently. Security tools help in regulatory compliance, encryption of sensitive data, and monitoring unauthorized access. Furthermore, collaboration tools included in these capabilities help in managing project workflows, document sharing, and video conferencing, thereby improving overall business efficiency.

On a Windows system, post-exploitation tools primarily focus on network management, ensuring proper connectivity and security throughout the network. They offer functionalities like bandwidth optimization, traffic monitoring, and the configuration of network devices such as routers and switches. Security aspects include setting up firewalls, managing VPNs, and monitoring for potential intrusions. Network diagnostic tools help in troubleshooting connectivity issues, ensuring optimal network performance, and maintaining smooth communication channels in both personal and professional environments.

Windows systems' post-exploitation tools encompass capabilities designed for developers, aiding in software development, testing, and deployment. These tools include integrated development environments (IDEs), code version control systems, and debugging utilities. They support various programming languages and facilitate the process of writing, compiling, and testing code. Other features include task automation, performance profiling, and API testing, ensuring developers can maintain high code quality and efficient software release cycles, catering to both individual programmers and large development teams.

The capabilities of Windows post-exploitation tools are focused on system backup, ensuring data integrity, and recovery solutions. These tools provide automated backup schedules, real-time data synchronization, and cloud storage integration. Users can restore entire systems or individual files in the event of data loss or corruption. Additional features include system image creation, incremental backups, and secure data deletion. These functionalities ensure that critical data is always retrievable and protected against unpredictable incidents such as hardware failures or cyber-attacks.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system that provides a comprehensive environment for multimedia, customization, and various user functionalities, including security and performance enhancements.

entities.name: POST-EXPLOITATION TOOLS
entities.description: Post-exploitation tools on Windows systems are designed to optimize software applications, enhance security features, and improve user experience across various functionalities.

entities.name: USER TRAINING PROGRAMS
entities.description: User training programs are initiatives aimed at educating users about phishing and social engineering techniques to enhance security awareness.

entities.name: SECURE BOOT
entities.description: Secure boot is a security measure that prevents unauthorized programs or operating systems from loading during the startup process.

entities.name: SYSTEM BACKUP
entities.description: System backup refers to the process of creating copies of data to ensure data integrity and recovery solutions in case of data loss.

entities.name: NETWORK MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Network management involves ensuring proper connectivity and security throughout the network, including bandwidth optimization and traffic monitoring.

entities.name: MULTIMEDIA USAGE
entities.description: Multimedia usage encompasses the capabilities of Windows systems to enhance graphics, video playback quality, and audio configurations for various applications.

entities.name: DEVELOPER TOOLS
entities.description: Developer tools on Windows systems aid in software development, testing, and deployment, including integrated development environments and debugging utilities.

entities.name: PHISHING
entities.description: Phishing is a type of social engineering attack aimed at tricking individuals into providing sensitive information.

entities.name: SOCIAL ENGINEERING
entities.description: Social engineering refers to manipulative tactics used to deceive individuals into divulging confidential information.

entities.name: USER ACCESS
entities.description: User access refers to the permissions and rights granted to users to interact with systems and data.

entities.name: DATA RECOVERY
entities.description: Data recovery is the process of restoring lost or inaccessible data from storage devices.

entities.name: ANTIVIRUS PROTECTION
entities.description: Antivirus protection involves software designed to detect and eliminate malware and other security threats.

entities.name: FIREWALL CONFIGURATIONS
entities.description: Firewall configurations are settings that control incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.

* Audit 
* User Account Management 
* User Training

Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

There are 2 software using the attack technique called Cloud Instance Metadata API. Their names are as follows:
* Peirates
* Hildegard

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Peirates
Software description: [Peirates](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0683) is a post-exploitation Kubernetes exploitation framework with a focus on gathering service account tokens for lateral movement and privilege escalation. The tool is written in GoLang and publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: Peirates GitHub)
Platforms: Containers

Software name: Hildegard
Software description: [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601) is malware that targets misconfigured kubelets for initial access and runs cryptocurrency miner operations. The malware was first observed in January 2021. The TeamTNT activity group is believed to be behind [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601). (Citation: Unit 42 Hildegard Malware)
Platforms: Linux, Containers, IaaS

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.description: Network Segmentation is a mitigation method that involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources to enhance security and prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts to ensure proper access control.

entities.name: RESTRICT REGISTRY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict Registry Permissions is a mitigation method that involves limiting the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry to protect system integrity.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that entails setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts to enhance security.

entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to the strategies employed to reduce the risk and impact of attack techniques like Service Stop.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 9 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Create or Modify System Process. Their names are as follows:
* User Account Management 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* Limit Software Installation 
* Privileged Account Management 
* Operating System Configuration 
* Audit 
* Software Configuration 
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 
* Code Signing 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Limit Software Installation
Mitigation method description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Software Configuration
Mitigation method description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Code Signing
Mitigation method description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems, including suspicious processes, files, and API calls.

entities.name: LIMIT SOFTWARE INSTALLATION
entities.description: Limit Software Installation is a mitigation method that blocks users or groups from installing unapproved software to maintain system integrity.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root accounts.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that involves making configuration changes related to the operating system to harden the system against various attack techniques.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: SOFTWARE CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Software Configuration is a mitigation method that implements changes to software configurations to mitigate security risks associated with how the software operates.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that sets directory and file permissions to restrict access, enhancing security.

entities.name: CODE SIGNING
entities.description: Code Signing is a mitigation method that enforces binary and application integrity through digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.name: CREATE OR MODIFY SYSTEM PROCESS
entities.description: Create or Modify System Process is an attack technique that involves unauthorized changes to system processes, which can compromise system security.

chunk:
There are 3 software using the attack technique called Security Support Provider. Their names are as follows:
* Mimikatz
* Empire
* PowerSploit

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Mimikatz
Software description: [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, along with many other features that make it useful for testing the security of networks. (Citation: Deply Mimikatz) (Citation: Adsecurity Mimikatz Guide)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Virtual Private Server. Their names are as follows:
* Pre-compromise 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Pre-compromise
Mitigation method description: This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

entities.name: VIRTUAL PRIVATE SERVER
entities.description: Virtual Private Server is an attack technique that requires mitigation methods to prevent adversaries from gaining initial access.

entities.name: PRE-COMPROMISE
entities.description: Pre-compromise is a mitigation method that applies to activities occurring before an adversary gains initial access, including reconnaissance and resource development techniques.

entities.name: INITIAL ACCESS
entities.description: Initial Access refers to the stage in a cyber attack where an adversary gains entry into a system or network.

entities.name: RECONNAISSANCE
entities.description: Reconnaissance is a technique used by adversaries to gather information about a target before launching an attack.

entities.name: RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT
entities.description: Resource Development involves the preparation and acquisition of resources necessary for executing an attack.

Software name: Net Crawler
Software description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) is an intranet worm capable of extracting credentials using credential dumpers and spreading to systems on a network over SMB by brute forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to execute a copy of [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056). (Citation: Cylance Cleaver)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 2 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Data from Configuration Repository. Their names are as follows:
* Network Device Configuration Dump
* SNMP (MIB Dump)

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Data from Configuration Repository
Attack technique description: Adversaries may collect data related to managed devices from configuration repositories. Configuration repositories are used by management systems in order to configure, manage, and control data on remote systems. Configuration repositories may also facilitate remote access and administration of devices.

Adversaries may target these repositories in order to collect large quantities of sensitive system administration data. Data from configuration repositories may be exposed by various protocols and software and can store a wide variety of data, much of which may align with adversary Discovery objectives.(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A)(Citation: US-CERT TA17-156A SNMP Abuse 2017)
Platforms: Network

Attack technique name: Network Device Configuration Dump
Attack technique description: Adversaries may access network configuration files to collect sensitive data about the device and the network. The network configuration is a file containing parameters that determine the operation of the device. The device typically stores an in-memory copy of the configuration while operating, and a separate configuration on non-volatile storage to load after device reset. Adversaries can inspect the configuration files to reveal information about the target network and its layout, the network device and its software, or identifying legitimate accounts and credentials for later use.

Adversaries can use common management tools and protocols, such as Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) and Smart Install (SMI), to access network configuration files.(Citation: US-CERT TA18-106A Network Infrastructure Devices 2018)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks) These tools may be used to query specific data from a configuration repository or configure the device to export the configuration for later analysis. 
Platforms: Network

Attack technique name: SNMP (MIB Dump)
Attack technique description: Adversaries may target the Management Information Base (MIB) to collect and/or mine valuable information in a network managed using Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

The MIB is a configuration repository that stores variable information accessible via SNMP in the form of object identifiers (OID). Each OID identifies a variable that can be read or set and permits active management tasks, such as configuration changes, through remote modification of these variables. SNMP can give administrators great insight in their systems, such as, system information, description of hardware, physical location, and software packages(Citation: SANS Information Security Reading Room Securing SNMP Securing SNMP). The MIB may also contain device operational information, including running configuration, routing table, and interface details.

Adversaries may use SNMP queries to collect MIB content directly from SNMP-managed devices in order to collect network information that allows the adversary to build network maps and facilitate future targeted exploitation.(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks) 
Platforms: Network

entities.description: Data from Configuration Repository is an attack technique where adversaries collect data related to managed devices from configuration repositories used by management systems to configure and control remote systems.

entities.name: NETWORK DEVICE CONFIGURATION DUMP
entities.description: Network Device Configuration Dump is an attack technique where adversaries access network configuration files to collect sensitive data about the device and the network.

entities.description: The Management Information Base (MIB) is a configuration repository that stores variable information accessible via SNMP, used for managing devices on a network.

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: LaZagne
Software description: [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system. It has modules for Windows, Linux, and OSX, but is mainly focused on Windows systems. [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: GitHub LaZagne Dec 2018)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: MimiPenguin
Software description: [MimiPenguin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0179) is a credential dumper, similar to [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002), designed specifically for Linux platforms. (Citation: MimiPenguin GitHub May 2017)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: PACEMAKER
Software description: [PACEMAKER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1109) is a credential stealer that was used by [APT5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1023) as early as 2020 including activity against US Defense Industrial Base (DIB) companies.(Citation: Mandiant Pulse Secure Zero-Day April 2021)
Platforms: Network, Linux

specifically for Linux platforms, similar to Mimikatz.</data>      <data key="d2">99d0fe1828920ae00da5b25067329f99</data>    </node>    <node id="PACEMAKER">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">PACEMAKER is a credential stealer used by APT5, targeting US Defense Industrial Base companies since 2020.</data>      <data key="d2">99d0fe1828920ae00da5b25067329f99</data>    </node>    <node id="US DEFENSE INDUSTRIAL BASE">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">The US Defense Industrial Base refers to the network of companies and organizations that provide products and services to the United States military and defense sector.)<|COMPLETE|></data>      <data key="d2">99d0fe1828920ae00da5b25067329f99</data>    </node>    <edge source="LAZAGNE" platforms (Windows vs. Linux)</data>      <data key="d5">99d0fe1828920ae00da5b25067329f99</data>    </edge>    <edge source="LAZAGNE" target="PACEMAKER">      <data key="d3">5.0</data>      <data There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Winlogon Helper DLL. Their names are as follows:
* Execution Prevention 
* User Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Fileless Storage. Their names are as follows:
* DarkWatchman
* PolyglotDuke
* QakBot
* TYPEFRAME
* ComRAT
* ShadowPad
* Gelsemium
* Uroburos
* SysUpdate
* Exaramel for Windows

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: DarkWatchman
Software description: [DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021.(Citation: Prevailion DarkWatchman 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PolyglotDuke
Software description: [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) is a downloader that has been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2013. [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) has been used to drop [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051).(Citation: ESET Dukes October 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TYPEFRAME
Software description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) is a remote access tool that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). (Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ComRAT
Software description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: NorthSec 2015 GData Uroburos Tools)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ShadowPad
Software description: [ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) is a modular backdoor that was first identified in a supply chain compromise of the NetSarang software in mid-July 2017. The malware was originally thought to be exclusively used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096), but has since been observed to be used by various Chinese threat activity groups. (Citation: Recorded Future RedEcho Feb 2021)(Citation: Securelist ShadowPad Aug 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky ShadowPad Aug 2017) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Gelsemium
Software description: [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) is a modular malware comprised of a dropper (Gelsemine), a loader (Gelsenicine), and main (Gelsevirine) plug-ins written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC) framework. [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) has been used by the Gelsemium group since at least 2014.(Citation: ESET Gelsemium June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Uroburos
Software description: [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool written in C that has been used by units within Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolset to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has several variants and has undergone nearly constant upgrade since its initial development in 2003 to keep it viable after public disclosures. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is typically deployed to external-facing nodes on a targeted network and has the ability to leverage additional tools and TTPs to further exploit an internal network. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, and can easily incorporate new or replacement components.(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
Platforms

entities.description: DarkWatchman is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021 and operates on Windows.

entities.name: POLYGLOTDUKE
entities.description: PolyglotDuke is a downloader used by APT29 since at least 2013, capable of dropping MiniDuke, and operates on Windows.

entities.name: QAKBOT
entities.description: QakBot is a modular banking trojan used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007, evolving into a delivery agent for ransomware, and operates on Windows.

entities.name: TYPEFRAME
entities.description: TYPEFRAME is a remote access tool used by the Lazarus Group and operates on Windows.

entities.name: COMRAT
entities.description: ComRAT is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of Agent.btz, used by Turla, and operates on Windows.

entities.name: SHADOWPAD
entities.description: ShadowPad is a modular backdoor first identified in a supply chain compromise of the NetSarang software in mid-July 2017, used by various Chinese threat activity groups, and operates on Windows.

entities.name: GELSEMIUM
entities.description: Gelsemium is a modular malware used by the Gelsemium group since at least 2014, consisting of a dropper, loader, and main plug-ins, and operates on Windows.

entities.name: UROBUROS
entities.description: Uroburos is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool used by Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the Turla toolset, designed for intelligence collection, and operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

entities.name: LAZARUS GROUP
entities.description: Lazarus Group is a state-sponsored hacking group from North Korea known for various cyber attacks and is associated with the use of TYPEFRAME.

entities.name: TURNA
entities.description: Turla is a Russian cyber espionage group known for its advanced malware and is associated with the use of ComRAT and Uroburos.

entities.name: NETSARANG
entities.description: NetSarang is a software company that was compromised in a supply chain attack involving ShadowPad.

entities.name: GELSEMIUM GROUP
entities.description: Gelsemium Group is a cyber threat actor known for using Gelsemium malware since at least 2014.

Software name: SysUpdate
Software description: [SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2020.(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: Exaramel for Windows
Software description: [Exaramel for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0343) is a backdoor used for targeting Windows systems. The Linux version is tracked separately under [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401).(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: THREAT GROUP-3390
entities.description: Threat Group-3390 is a cyber threat group that has been using the SysUpdate backdoor since at least 2020.

entities.name: SYSUPDATE
entities.description: SysUpdate is a backdoor software written in C++ utilized by Threat Group-3390 for cyber exploitation.

entities.name: EXARAMEL FOR WINDOWS
entities.description: Exaramel for Windows is a backdoor targeting Windows systems, with a separate Linux version available.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that is targeted by various cyber threat groups, including Uroburos and Threat Group-3390.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that is targeted by various cyber threat groups, including Uroburos, Threat Group-3390, and Exaramel.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that is targeted by Uroburos for cyber exploitation.

entities.name: KASPERSKY
entities.description: Kaspersky is a cybersecurity company that provides insights and research on various cyber threats, including the Uroburos malware.

entities.name: JOINT CYBERSECURITY ADVISORY
entities.description: The Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A is an event that provides information and warnings about cyber threats, including Snake Malware.

chunk:
There are 2 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Disk Wipe. Their names are as follows:
* Disk Structure Wipe
* Disk Content Wipe

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Disk Wipe
Attack technique description: Adversaries may wipe or corrupt raw disk data on specific systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources. With direct write access to a disk, adversaries may attempt to overwrite portions of disk data. Adversaries may opt to wipe arbitrary portions of disk data and/or wipe disk structures like the master boot record (MBR). A complete wipe of all disk sectors may be attempted.

To maximize impact on the target organization in operations where network-wide availability interruption is the goal, malware used for wiping disks may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging additional techniques like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware)

On network devices, adversaries may wipe configuration files and other data from the device using [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands such as `erase`.(Citation: erase_cmd_cisco)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows, Network

Attack technique name: Disk Structure Wipe
Attack technique description: Adversaries may corrupt or wipe the disk data structures on a hard drive necessary to boot a system; targeting specific critical systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources. 

Adversaries may attempt to render the system unable to boot by overwriting critical data located in structures such as the master boot record (MBR) or partition table.(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018) The data contained in disk structures may include the initial executable code for loading an operating system or the location of the file system partitions on disk. If this information is not present, the computer will not be able to load an operating system during the boot process, leaving the computer unavailable. [Disk Structure Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/002) may be performed in isolation, or along with [Disk Content Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/001) if all sectors of a disk are wiped.

On a network devices, adversaries may reformat the file system using [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands such as `format`.(Citation: format_cmd_cisco)

To maximize impact on the target organization, malware designed for destroying disk structures may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging other techniques like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows, Network

Attack technique name: Disk Content Wipe
Attack technique description: Adversaries may erase the contents of storage devices on specific systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources.

Adversaries may partially or completely overwrite the contents of a storage device rendering the data irrecoverable through the storage interface.(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster)(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware)(Citation: DOJ Lazarus Sony 2018) Instead of wiping specific disk structures or files, adversaries with destructive intent may wipe arbitrary portions of disk content. To wipe disk content, adversaries may acquire direct access to the hard drive in order to overwrite arbitrarily sized portions of disk with random data.(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware) Adversaries have also been observed leveraging third-party drivers like [RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364) to directly access disk content.(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster)(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware) This behavior is distinct from [Data Destruction](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485) because sections of the disk are erased instead of individual files.

To maximize impact on the target organization in operations where network-wide availability interruption is the goal, malware used for wiping disk content may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging additional techniques like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows, Network

entities.name: DISK WIPE
entities.description: Disk Wipe is an attack technique where adversaries may wipe or corrupt raw disk data on specific systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources.

entities.name: DISK STRUCTURE WIPE
entities.description: Disk Structure Wipe is a specific attack technique that corrupts or wipes the disk data structures necessary to boot a system, targeting critical systems to interrupt availability.

entities.name: DISK CONTENT WIPE
entities.description: Disk Content Wipe is an attack technique where adversaries erase the contents of storage devices to interrupt availability to system and network resources.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that can be targeted by attack techniques such as Disk Wipe, Disk Structure Wipe, and Disk Content Wipe.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that can be targeted by attack techniques such as Disk Wipe, Disk Structure Wipe, and Disk Content Wipe.

entities.name: NETWORK
entities.description: Network refers to a system of interconnected devices that can be targeted by attack techniques such as Disk Wipe, Disk Structure Wipe, and Disk Content Wipe.

chunk:
There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Data from Removable Media. Their names are as follows:
* Data Loss Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Data Loss Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.(Citation: PurpleSec Data Loss Prevention)

entities.name: DATA LOSS PREVENTION
entities.description: Data Loss Prevention is a mitigation method that categorizes sensitive data, identifies formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restricts the exfiltration of sensitive data.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation methods are strategies or techniques used to reduce the risk of data breaches and protect sensitive information.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Internet Connection Discovery. Their names are as follows:
* GoldFinder
* More_eggs
* Neoichor
* SUGARUSH
* NKAbuse
* QakBot
* QuietSieve
* SysUpdate
* DarkTortilla
* Woody RAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: GoldFinder
Software description: [GoldFinder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0597) is a custom HTTP tracer tool written in Go that logs the route a packet takes between a compromised network and a C2 server. It can be used to inform  threat actors of potential points of discovery or logging of their actions, including C2 related to other malware. [GoldFinder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0597) was discovered in early 2021 during an investigation into the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024) by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016).(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: More_eggs
Software description: [More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) is a JScript backdoor used by [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) and [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037). Its name was given based on the variable "More_eggs" being present in its code. There are at least two different versions of the backdoor being used, version 2.0 and version 4.4. (Citation: Talos Cobalt Group July 2018)(Citation: Security Intelligence More Eggs Aug 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Neoichor
Software description: [Neoichor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0691) is C2 malware used by [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) since at least 2019; similar malware families used by the group include Leeson and Numbldea.(Citation: Microsoft NICKEL December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SUGARUSH
Software description: [SUGARUSH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1049) is a small custom backdoor that can establish a reverse shell over TCP to a hard coded C2 address. [SUGARUSH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1049) was first identified during analysis of UNC3890's [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010) campaign targeting Israeli companies, which began in late 2020.(Citation: Mandiant UNC3890 Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NKAbuse
Software description: [NKAbuse](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1107) is a Go-based, multi-platform malware abusing NKN (New Kind of Network) technology for data exchange between peers, functioning as a potent implant, and equipped with both flooder and backdoor capabilities.(Citation: NKAbuse BC)(Citation: NKAbuse SL)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuietSieve
Software description: [QuietSieve](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0686) is an information stealer that has been used by [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) since at least 2021.(Citation: Microsoft Actinium February 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SysUpdate
Software description: [SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2020.(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: DarkTortilla
Software description: [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) is a highly configurable .NET-based crypter that has been possibly active since at least August 2015. [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has been used to deliver popular information stealers, RATs, and payloads such as [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), AsyncRat, [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336), RedLine, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154), and Metasploit.(Citation: Secureworks

entities.name: NEOICHOR
entities.description: Neoichor is C2 malware used by Ke3chang since at least 2019, similar to other malware families used by the group.

entities.name: SUGARUSH
entities.description: SUGARUSH is a small custom backdoor that establishes a reverse shell over TCP to a hard coded C2 address, identified during analysis of UNC3890's campaign targeting Israeli companies.

entities.name: NKABUSE
entities.description: NKAbuse is a Go-based, multi-platform malware that abuses NKN technology for data exchange, functioning as a potent implant with flooder and backdoor capabilities.

entities.name: QAKBOT
entities.description: QakBot is a modular banking trojan used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007, evolving from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware.

entities.name: QUIETSIEVE
entities.description: QuietSieve is an information stealer used by Gamaredon Group since at least 2021.

entities.name: SYSUPDATE
entities.description: SysUpdate is a backdoor written in C++ used by Threat Group-3390 since at least 2020.

entities.name: DARKTORTILLA
entities.description: DarkTortilla is a highly configurable .NET-based crypter used to deliver various information stealers and payloads, possibly active since at least August 2015.

entities.name: COBALT GROUP
entities.description: Cobalt Group is a cybercriminal group known for using various malware, including the More_eggs backdoor.

entities.name: FIN6
entities.description: FIN6 is a cybercriminal group that has been involved in various financial crimes and is known to use the More_eggs backdoor.

entities.name: KE3CHANG

entities.name: UNC3890

entities.name: NKN

entities.name: THREAT GROUP-3390

entities.description: Information stealers are a category of malware designed to collect sensitive information from victims, which DarkTortilla is used to deliver.)<|COMPLETE|>

5. [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has been used to deliver popular information stealers, RATs, and payloads such as [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), AsyncRat, [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336), RedLine, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154), and Metasploit.(Citation: Secureworks DarkTortilla Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Woody RAT
Software description:  [Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that has been used since at least August 2021 against Russian organizations.(Citation: MalwareBytes WoodyRAT Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows
