chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Cloud Instance Metadata API. Their names are as follows:
* Limit Access to Resource Over Network 
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Filter Network Traffic 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Mitigation method description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: CLOUD INSTANCE METADATA API
entities.description: The Cloud Instance Metadata API is an attack technique that can be exploited, necessitating mitigation methods to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: LIMIT ACCESS TO RESOURCE OVER NETWORK
entities.description:
A specific mitigation method that prevents unauthorized access to file shares and remote systems to enhance security.
A mitigation method that involves preventing access to file shares and remote systems to enhance security.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description:
A mitigation method that focuses on removing or denying access to unnecessary software to reduce vulnerabilities.
A specific mitigation method that involves removing or denying access to unnecessary software to reduce potential vulnerabilities.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description:
A mitigation method that employs network appliances to filter traffic and enhance security protocols.
A specific mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter traffic and perform protocol-based filtering to enhance security.

chunk:
There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Search Victim-Owned Websites. Their names are as follows:

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Search Victim-Owned Websites
Attack technique description: Adversaries may search websites owned by the victim for information that can be used during targeting. Victim-owned websites may contain a variety of details, including names of departments/divisions, physical locations, and data about key employees such as names, roles, and contact info (ex: [Email Addresses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1589/002)). These sites may also have details highlighting business operations and relationships.(Citation: Comparitech Leak)

Adversaries may search victim-owned websites to gather actionable information. Information from these sources may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Establish Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1585) or [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)), and/or initial access (ex: [Trusted Relationship](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1199) or [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566)).
Platforms: PRE

attacks.</data>      <data key="d5">c765c7e305be0f0487f698270f055d9d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SEARCH VICTIM-OWNED WEBSITES" target="SEARCH OPEN TECHNICAL DATABASES">      <data key="d3">5.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques are part of the reconnaissance phase where adversaries gather information about potential targets.</data>      <data key="d5">c765c7e305be0f0487f698270f055d9d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SEARCH VICTIM-OWNED WEBSITES" target="ESTABLISH ACCOUNTS">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">Information from victim-owned websites can assist adversaries in establishing accounts for further attacks.</data>      <data key="d5">c765c7e305be0f0487f698270f055d9d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SEARCH VICTIM-OWNED WEBSITES" target="COMPROMISE ACCOUNTS">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">Data obtained from victim-owned websites may help adversaries in compromising accounts.</data> chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Security Account Manager. Their names are as follows:
* CrackMapExec
* gsecdump
* Koadic
* pwdump
* Mimikatz
* Impacket
* Fgdump
* HOPLIGHT
* Remsec
* CozyCar

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: CrackMapExec
Software description: [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488), or CME, is a post-exploitation tool developed in Python and designed for penetration testing against networks. [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488) collects Active Directory information to conduct lateral movement through targeted networks.(Citation: CME Github September 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: gsecdump
Software description: [gsecdump](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0008) is a publicly-available credential dumper used to obtain password hashes and LSA secrets from Windows operating systems. (Citation: TrueSec Gsecdump)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Koadic
Software description: [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: pwdump
Software description: [pwdump](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0006) is a credential dumper. (Citation: Wikipedia pwdump)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mimikatz
Software description: [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, along with many other features that make it useful for testing the security of networks. (Citation: Deply Mimikatz) (Citation: Adsecurity Mimikatz Guide)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Impacket
Software description: [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols. [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) contains several tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.(Citation: Impacket Tools)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Fgdump
Software description: [Fgdump](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0120) is a Windows password hash dumper. (Citation: Mandiant APT1)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HOPLIGHT
Software description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) is a backdoor Trojan that has reportedly been used by the North Korean government.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remsec
Software description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is a modular backdoor that has been used by [Strider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0041) and appears to have been designed primarily for espionage purposes. Many of its modules are written in Lua. (Citation: Symantec Strider Blog)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CozyCar
Software description: [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. It is a modular malware platform, and its backdoor component can be instructed to download and execute a variety of modules with different functionality. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow. Their names are as follows:
* Privileged Account Management 
* Password Policies 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies is a mitigation method that sets and enforces secure password policies for accounts.

entities.name: ATTACK TECHNIQUE
entities.description: The attack technique called /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow refers to methods used to exploit vulnerabilities in system account management.

chunk: There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Screen Capture. Their names are as follows: The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: Screen Capture Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to take screen captures of the desktop to gather information over the course of an operation. Screen capturing functionality may be included as a feature of a remote access tool used in post-compromise operations. Taking a screenshot is also typically possible through native utilities or API calls, such as CopyFromScreen, xwd, or screencapture.(Citation: CopyFromScreen .NET)(Citation: Antiquated Mac Malware) Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: OSX/Shlayer
Software description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) is a Trojan designed to install adware on macOS that was first discovered in 2018.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)(Citation: Intego Shlayer Feb 2018)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Bundlore
Software description: [Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482) is adware written for macOS that has been in use since at least 2015. Though categorized as adware, [Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482) has many features associated with more traditional backdoors.(Citation: MacKeeper Bundlore Apr 2019)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: WarzoneRAT
Software description: [WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670) is a malware-as-a-service remote access tool (RAT) written in C++ that has been publicly available for purchase since at least late 2018.(Citation: Check Point Warzone Feb 2020)(Citation: Uptycs Warzone UAC Bypass November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DarkTortilla
Software description: [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) is a highly configurable .NET-based crypter that has been possibly active since at least August 2015. [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has been used to deliver popular information stealers, RATs, and payloads such as [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), AsyncRat, [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336), RedLine, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154), and Metasploit.(Citation: Secureworks DarkTortilla Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Tarrask
Software description: [Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) is malware that has been used by [HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) since at least August 2021. [Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) was designed to evade digital defenses and maintain persistence by generating concealed scheduled tasks.(Citation: Tarrask scheduled task)
Platforms: Windows

* Data Backup 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Data Backup
Mitigation method description: Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.

entities.name: DATA BACKUP
entities.description: Data Backup is a mitigation method that involves taking and storing data backups from end user systems and critical servers to prevent data loss from attacks such as Disk Wipe.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to strategies and techniques employed to prevent or reduce the impact of cyber attacks, such as Disk Wipe.

There are 2 software using the attack technique called Pluggable Authentication Modules. Their names are as follows:
* Ebury
* Skidmap

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Ebury
Software description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) is an SSH backdoor targeting Linux operating systems. Attackers require root-level access, which allows them to replace SSH binaries (ssh, sshd, ssh-add, etc) or modify a shared library used by OpenSSH (libkeyutils).(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)(Citation: BleepingComputer Ebury March 2017)(Citation: ESET Ebury Oct 2017)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: Skidmap
Software description: [Skidmap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0468) is a kernel-mode rootkit used for cryptocurrency mining.(Citation: Trend Micro Skidmap)
Platforms: Linux

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system that serves as the platform for both Ebury and Skidmap, making it a target for these malicious software.

chunk:
There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Direct Volume Access. Their names are as follows:

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Direct Volume Access
Attack technique description: Adversaries may directly access a volume to bypass file access controls and file system monitoring. Windows allows programs to have direct access to logical volumes. Programs with direct access may read and write files directly from the drive by analyzing file system data structures. This technique may bypass Windows file access controls as well as file system monitoring tools. (Citation: Hakobyan 2009)

Utilities, such as `NinjaCopy`, exist to perform these actions in PowerShell.(Citation: Github PowerSploit Ninjacopy) Adversaries may also use built-in or third-party utilities (such as `vssadmin`, `wbadmin`, and [esentutl](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0404)) to create shadow copies or backups of data from system volumes.(Citation: LOLBAS Esentutl)
Platforms: Windows, Network

entities.name: DIRECT VOLUME ACCESS
entities.description: Direct Volume Access is an attack technique that allows adversaries to directly access a volume to bypass file access controls and file system monitoring on Windows systems.

entities.name: NINJACOPY
entities.description: NinjaCopy is a utility that performs actions to directly access volumes in PowerShell, allowing for bypassing of file access controls.

entities.name: VSSADMIN
entities.description: VSSADMIN is a built-in utility in Windows that can be used to create shadow copies or backups of data from system volumes.

entities.name: WBADMIN
entities.description: WBADMIN is a built-in Windows utility that allows users to perform backup and recovery operations, including creating shadow copies.

entities.name: ESENTUTL
entities.description: Esentutl is a third-party utility that can be used to manage and manipulate database files, including creating backups.

entities.name: NETWORK
entities.description: Network refers to the platform that can also be targeted by the Direct Volume Access attack technique, allowing for potential data breaches.

There are 10 software using the attack technique called Archive via Custom Method. Their names are as follows:
* Attor
* BLUELIGHT
* Duqu
* Stuxnet
* SPACESHIP
* FoggyWeb
* NETWIRE
* Rising Sun
* StrongPity
* RGDoor

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Attor
Software description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) is a Windows-based espionage platform that has been seen in use since 2013. [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a loadable plugin architecture to customize functionality for specific targets.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BLUELIGHT
Software description: [BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) is a remote access Trojan used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) that was first observed in early 2021.(Citation: Volexity InkySquid BLUELIGHT August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Duqu
Software description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) is a malware platform that uses a modular approach to extend functionality after deployment within a target network. (Citation: Symantec W32.Duqu)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Stuxnet
Software description: [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was the first publicly reported piece of malware to specifically target industrial control systems devices. [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) is a large and complex piece of malware that utilized multiple different behaviors including multiple zero-day vulnerabilities, a sophisticated Windows rootkit, and network infection routines.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011)(Citation: CISA ICS Advisory ICSA-10-272-01)(Citation: ESET Stuxnet Under the Microscope)(Citation: Langer Stuxnet) [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was discovered in 2010, with some components being used as early as November 2008.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SPACESHIP
Software description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) is malware developed by [APT30](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0013) that allows propagation and exfiltration of data over removable devices. [APT30](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0013) may use this capability to exfiltrate data across air-gaps. (Citation: FireEye APT30)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FoggyWeb
Software description: [FoggyWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0661) is a passive and highly-targeted backdoor capable of remotely exfiltrating sensitive information from a compromised Active Directory Federated Services (AD FS) server. It has been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least early April 2021.(Citation: MSTIC FoggyWeb September 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NETWIRE
Software description: [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) that has been used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: McAfee Netwire Mar 2015)(Citation: FireEye APT33 Webinar Sept 2017)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Rising Sun
Software description: [Rising Sun](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0448) is a modular backdoor that was used extensively in [Operation Sharpshooter](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0013) between 2017 and 2019. [Rising Sun](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0448) infected at least 87 organizations around the world, including nuclear, defense, energy, and financial service companies. Security researchers assessed [Rising Sun](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0448) included some source code from [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032)'s Trojan Duuzer.(Citation: McAfee Sharpshooter December 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: StrongPity
Software description: [StrongPity](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0491) is an information stealing malware used by [PROMETHIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0056).(Citation: Bitdefender StrongPity June 2020)(Citation: Talos Promethium June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RGDoor
Software description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) is a malicious Internet Information Services (IIS) backdoor developed in the C++ language. [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) has been seen deployed on webservers belonging to the Middle East government organizations. [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S025

Software name: RGDoor
Software description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) is a malicious Internet Information Services (IIS) backdoor developed in the C++ language. [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) has been seen deployed on webservers belonging to the Middle East government organizations. [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) provides backdoor access to compromised IIS servers. (Citation: Unit 42 RGDoor Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 6 software using the attack technique called OS Credential Dumping. Their names are as follows:
* Carbanak
* Revenge RAT
* PinchDuke
* OnionDuke
* HOMEFRY
* Trojan.Karagany

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Carbanak
Software description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) is a full-featured, remote backdoor used by a group of the same name ([Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008)). It is intended for espionage, data exfiltration, and providing remote access to infected machines. (Citation: Kaspersky Carbanak) (Citation: FireEye CARBANAK June 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Revenge RAT
Software description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PinchDuke
Software description: [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2008 to 2010. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: OnionDuke
Software description: [OnionDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0052) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2013 to 2015. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HOMEFRY
Software description: [HOMEFRY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0232) is a 64-bit Windows password dumper/cracker that has previously been used in conjunction with other [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) backdoors. (Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Trojan.Karagany
Software description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) is a modular remote access tool used for recon and linked to [Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035). The source code for [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) originated from Dream Loader malware which was leaked in 2010 and sold on underground forums. (Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)(Citation: Secureworks Karagany July 2019)(Citation: Dragos DYMALLOY )
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 3 software using the attack technique called Run Virtual Instance. Their names are as follows:
* Maze
* Ragnar Locker
* LoudMiner

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Maze
Software description: [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) ransomware, previously known as "ChaCha", was discovered in May 2019. In addition to encrypting files on victim machines for impact, [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) operators conduct information stealing campaigns prior to encryption and post the information online to extort affected companies.(Citation: FireEye Maze May 2020)(Citation: McAfee Maze March 2020)(Citation: Sophos Maze VM September 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ragnar Locker
Software description: [Ragnar Locker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0481) is a ransomware that has been in use since at least December 2019.(Citation: Sophos Ragnar May 2020)(Citation: Cynet Ragnar Apr 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LoudMiner
Software description: [LoudMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0451) is a cryptocurrency miner which uses virtualization software to siphon system resources. The miner has been bundled with pirated copies of Virtual Studio Technology (VST) for Windows and macOS.(Citation: ESET LoudMiner June 2019)
Platforms: macOS, Windows

entities.name: MAZE
entities.description: Maze is a ransomware software that encrypts files on victim machines and conducts information stealing campaigns prior to encryption, discovered in May 2019.

entities.name: RAGNAR LOCKER
entities.description: Ragnar Locker is a ransomware software that has been in use since at least December 2019.

entities.name: LOUDMINER
entities.description: LoudMiner is a cryptocurrency miner that uses virtualization software to siphon system resources and has been bundled with pirated copies of Virtual Studio Technology for Windows and macOS.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform on which LoudMiner operates.
